title: What's a book that's worth learning the language it was written in, just to read the original version? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most books originally written in a Latin language beg to be read in a Latin language. It might be true for Mandarin and Swahili as well. I just don’t know.But all translations from a Latin language, be it Spanish, Italian, Portuguese, Romanian into English are losing half of the music. Around the 19th century, English started to bleed syntax. As of now, it has maybe 20% of its original syntax, let alone that maybe 70% of its humongous vocabulary is useless for the basic reason that readers don’t (want to) know it anymore. The problem is not losing per se, but losing precision on one hand, and musicality on the other. There are books so powerful that are able to transcend this phenomenon. For example “A Hundred Years of Solitude.”Transcending though doesn’t mean that the book gives the English reader the same as it gives to the Spanish reader, it just means the story was so powerful that the mutilating translation didn’t manage to kill it completely.
